Sentencas: This work is concerned with identification of Wiener models (a linear dynamic part connected in series with a nonlinear dynamic one).
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell

Sentencas: A neural network with one hidden layer is used as the nonlinear block of the model, two network configurations are considered.
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell

Sentencas: For model identification three algorithms are described.
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell

Sentencas: In the first case model accuracy only in transient conditions is considered, only the dynamic data is used for model training.
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell

Sentencas: In the next two algorithms model accuracy in both transient and steady-state conditions is considered, dynamic and steady-state data sets are used.
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell

Sentencas: The steady-state model errors are taken into account by an additional term in the minimized cost-function or by additional inequality constraints.
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell

Sentencas: For comparison of discussed algorithms and model structures, identification of a Wiener model of a solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) process is considered.
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell

Sentencas: It is shown that the best results are obtained by the algorithm 2 which minimizes at the same time both dynamic and steady-state model errors, additional constraints used in the algorithm 3 are computationally quite demanding.
Titulo: Identification of Wiener models for dynamic and steady-state performance with application to solid oxide fuel cell
